response.answer_text: How important was Frederick Douglass to slavery? Important to slavery? Not very much. Important to the Abolishement of chattel slavery? Very. Through his autobiographies, essays and public speeches, he was able to capture the minds and often the hearts of many of the White people who followed his work. Before Blacks were finally able to really voice their stories about their lives as slaves, Whites often only had access to pseudo-scientific documents or racist literature that, in one way or the other, stated that Blacks were generally happy as slavesWere too simple minded for any other workWere genetically built for back breaking laborWere cursed by God himself to a life of laborDidn’t feel pain in the same way as WhitesWeren’t really humanIt wasn’t until they began to hear and read from former slaves, who were intelligent and could eloquently explain what life was like as a slave in this country, that people began to slowly understand that what they were doing was wrong. And that they were doing it to other human beings with family, hopes, dreams and feelings that were just like theirs. One of the minds that he (and others like him) was able to touch was Harriett Beecher Stowe. This proved to be the nail in the coffin for Slavery as the White woman set down to write a ficionalized book about slavery that simply regurgitated the real stories she previously read. But now it came from a White person…. so it must be true. We have people like Frederick DouglassOlaudah EquianoHarriet WilsonHarriet Ann JacobsJosiah Hensonand even Richard HildrethTo thank for that. Robert, Frederick Douglass wasn’t at all important to slavery. What Douglass represented was slavery’s terrible weakness. The fact is that we were NOT all created equal. Some of us are gifted in music, mechanically, as athletes, or with the ability to think. We all have different abilities and gifts, which means we were all created unique and different. The reason bonded labor systems (e.g., slavery and serfdom) have been the rule since humans abandoned the hunter/gatherer lifestyle is for social stability. For slaves and serfs, at least in theory, all they had to do was what they were told and their needs were met, with their thinking done for them. There was no worry about the least capable making rash, bad decisions. Most people are poor as a result of an inability or unwillingness to make good decisions. This is why reactive movements—such as communism, socialism, fascism, and now ethnonationalism—have followed liberalism for its entire existence. A competitive system in which the sky is the limit is as bad for the least talented people as it is good for the most talented. Socialism and communism are merely the latest manifestations of systems designed to do the thinking for ordinary people. Along with other black critics of slavery, Douglass was obviously very bright, and thus found it intolerable to be required to let others do his thinking for him. What is needed is a system that is good for both the least and most talented. And that’s not what we have now.

Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass  Former slave, impassioned abolitionist, brilliant writer, newspaper editor and eloquent orator whose speeches fired the abolitionist cause, Frederick Douglass (1818–1895) led an astounding life. Physical abuse, deprivation and tragedy plagued his early years, yet through sheer force of character he was able to overcome these obstacles to become a leading spokesman for his people.In this, the first and most frequently read of his three autobiographies, Douglass provides graphic descriptions of his childhood and horrifying experiences as a slave as well as a harrowing record of his dramatic escape to the North and eventual freedom.Published in 1845 to quell doubts about his origins — since few slaves of that period could write — the Narrative is admired today for its extraordinary passion, sensitive and vivid descriptions and storytelling power. It belongs in the library of anyone interested in African-American history and the life of one of the country's most courageous and influential champions of civil rights.

He was very important to the abolitionist movement and the eventual end of slavery in the USA. Frederick Douglass was the most prominent abolitionist and was formerly a slave. He escaped slavery, became an excellent speaker and writer, helped end the stereotypes concerning the ability of former slaves, and gave his voice and pen to the growing anti-slavery movement in the USA and also Great Britain and Ireland. For Douglass’s moderate views, see Prison & Slavery - A Surprising Comparison: John Dewar Gleissner: Amazon.com: Books.

As a black man able to eloquently speak and lecture before audiences about evil of slavery and his own first-hand experience, he was very effective at convincing whites that black people were intelligent, moral human beings and worthy of the same rights that white people enjoyed.
